No clue to the teenagers' whereabouts, had turned up, but the operation, in crippling Hamas's infrastructure, had been a success.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=706997 |title=West Bank crackdown 'to end in days' |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=23 June 2014}} Netanyahu declared: "We've pretty much figured out who are the kidnappers—the actual perpetrators, the supporters, the command structure—and there's no question, these are members of Hamas." ====Day 12==== [[File:Nursery after search 24 June 2014.JPG|thumbnail|Mess in Hebron home after IDF search, 24 June 2014]] On 24 June 120 buildings were searched and four to 13{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707286 |title=Israeli forces raid Hebron district overnight, 'arrest 13' |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=24 June 2014}} Palestinians were rounded up by Israeli forces in the Hebron area, Beit Kahil, Beit Awwa, [[Al-Arroub (camp)|al-Arrub refugee camp]], and the Hebron neighbourhoods of al-Mahawir, al-Bassa, and al-Hawooz, bringing the number of sites examined to 1,800 and the number of detained Palestinians, in the IDF calculation, to 354,{{cite news |first=Gavriel |last=Fiske |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/four-arrested-overnight-in-west-bank-as-sweep-continues/ |title=Four arrested overnight in West Bank as sweep continues |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=24 June 2014}} or according to Palestinian sources, over 500. As town searches and arrests wound down, investigators shifted their focus to interrogations of detainees and scrutiny of the 150 security cameras in the area in which the kidnapping is believed to have taken place.{{cite news |first1=Elior |last1=Levy |first2=Yoav |last2=Zitun |first3=Attila |last3=Somfalvi |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4534057,00.html |title=Hebron returning to normal as Shin Bet looks for new leads on kidnapped teens |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=24 June 2014}} The IDF said it had no substantial lead on the boys' whereabouts, or fate.{{cite news |first=Yoav |last=Zitun |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4534155,00.html |title=IDF Chief: As time passes, concerns grow regarding fate of boys |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=24 June 2014}} A lawyer for the PA said that in the wake of the West Bank round-up, the number of Palestinian minors detained in Israeli jails exceeded 250, and that the hunt for the missing Israeli youths served to cover up this fact.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707519 |title=Number of Palestinian children in Israeli jails 'surpasses 250' |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=24 June 2014 |quote=Over the past decade, Israeli forces have arrested, interrogated, and prosecuted around 7,000 children between 12 and 17, mostly boys, at a rate of "an average of two children each day", UNICEF said.}} ====Day 13==== On 25 June, 17 Palestinians were arrested overnight in Yatta, Beit Ummar, Hebron and Bethlehem among them legislative council members Khalid Tafish and Anwar Zaboun,{{cite news |author=Yoav Zitun |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4534303,00.html |title=Video: Hamas operative's arrest through the lens of the Skylark UAV |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=25 June 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707700 |title=Israeli forces detain Palestinian lawmakers, Hamas leaders overnight|work= [[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=25 June 2014}} both of Bethlehem, bringing the number of Palestinian legislators arrested in the campaign to 12.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707782 |title=23 Palestinian members of parliament in Israeli jails |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=25 June 2014}} Of the 19 people arrested in Beit Ummar since the start of the search, 14 are minors. A Palestinian youth in [[Khursa]], Younis al-Rjoub (18), was shot in the abdomen during a clash with Israeli soldiers.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707877 |title=Israeli forces shoot and injure Palestinian near Hebron |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=25 June 2014}} ====Day 14==== On 26 June, the Israel Security Agency released the names of two Hamas suspects.{{cite news|publisher =Reuters |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/26/israel-suspects-teens-kidnapping_n_5534281.html |title= Israel Names Two Suspects In Kidnapping of Teens |work=The Huffington Post |date= 25 June 2014 |accessdate=29 June 2014}} The ISA stated that both men had engaged in terrorism, been arrested and served time in the past, and were immediately considered suspects. ISA and Palestinian authorities said they had disappeared from their homes on the night of the kidnapping, and ISA believed them to be integral members of the kidnapping group.{{cite news|place=UK |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/10929615/Israel-identifies-two-suspects-in-case-of-kidnapped-teens.html |title= Israel identifies two suspects in case of kidnapped teens |work=The Telegraph |accessdate=29 June 2014}} Overnight, 136 structures were searched and a further 10 Palestinians were arrested in the Hebron area on suspicion of being terrorists. Fatima Ismail Issa Rushdi (78) died of a heart attack during an Israeli raid on the Arruba refugee camp. Nine youths were injured by tear gas or rubber bullets. Two boys, aged 13 and 14, were arrested in Dura.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707937 |title=78-year-old woman dies of heart attack during Israeli raid |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=26 June 2014}} 44-year-old Ismail Ahmad al-Hawamda was shot in the foot, running away from a checkpoint in the Hebron district town of al-Samu.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707940 |title=Israeli forces shoot, injure Palestinian at Hebron checkpoint |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=26 June 2014}} Despite the [[Oslo Accords]] stipulating coordination with the PA security service for Israeli entry into West Bank Areas in the [[Oslo II Accord|Area A]], in what was called an "unprecedented" move, Israeli units raided the Tunis and [[Rafidia]] neighbourhoods of Nablus and Balata refugee camp without prior clearance. Two hundred homes in Awarta were also raided.{{cite news|url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=707973|title=Israel raids Nablus without notifying Palestinian security|work=Ma'an News Agency|date=26 June 2014}} According to Israeli figures, state detentions numbered 381, of whom 282 are affiliated to Hamas. The number of locations searched rose to 1,955, including 64 Hamas institutions. Palestinian figures state that 566 were detained, six were shot dead, and over 120 wounded; two elderly people died of heart attacks during Israeli operations, and more than 1,200 homes were searched.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=708055 |title=Group: 566 Palestinians detained since Israeli campaign began |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=26 June 2014}} ===Week 3 (27 June – 3 July)=== ====Day 18==== [[File:קברי הנערים ב.jpg|thumb|300px|Graves of the three teenagers, [[Modi'in-Maccabim-Re'ut|Modi'in]] Cemetery]] On 30 June, a search team located the bound bodies of the three boys on land purchased recently by the [[Qawasameh tribe|Qawasmeh]] family in an open field near Khirbet Aranava in the [[Nahal Telem|Wadi Tellem]] area, between Halhul and [[Karmei Tzur]], about {{convert|3|km|mi}} west of the former, just north of Hebron.{{cite news |first1=Gili |last1=Cohen |first2=Barak |last2=Ravid |first3=Jack |last3=Khoury |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.602189 |type=live updates |title=Israeli forces find bodies of three kidnapped teens |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=30 June 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4536378,00.html |title=IDF finds missing teens' bodies in West Bank |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=30 June 2014}} A high security source revealed that: {{Quote |The quick solving of the crime by the Shin Bet, which within a 24-hour period identified the kidnappers, together with military pressure in the field, prevented the kidnappers from hiding the bodies and negotiating with Israel for their return.}} The ambulance carrying the three bodies was attacked by Palestinians as it left Halhul, the location where the bodies had been found. The Palestinians hurled rocks and paint at the ambulance, smashing its windshield and blinding the windows, but failed to cause the driver to lose control.{{cite news |url=http://www.jewishpress.com/news/breaking-news/pa-arabs-attack-idf-ambulance-carrying-teens-bodies/2014/07/01/ |title=PA Arabs attack IDF ambulance carrying teens' bodies |accessdate=1 July 2014 |date=30 June 2014}} Just after midnight, Israeli military used explosives to demolish the Hebron homes of the two main suspects, Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/01/world/middleeast/Israel-missing-teenagers.html |title=Israel's Search for 3 Teenagers Ends in Grief |first1=Jodi |last1=Rudoren |first2=Isabel |last2=Kershner |date=30 June 2014 |newspaper=The New York Times}} ====Day 19==== The joint funeral of Yifrach, Fraenkel, and Shaer was scheduled for 17:30 on 1 July. Huge crowds delayed it for over an hour. Israeli jets and helicopters struck 34 locations in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip in response to more than 20 rockets being fired at Israel from Gaza. A 19-year-old Palestinian man, Yousouf Al-Zagha, was shot dead by Israeli troops during a raid in the northern town of Jenin. An IDF spokesperson said the man had thrown a grenade at the troops, while his family maintained he had been carrying eggs home for [[suhoor]], the predawn meal during the fast of Ramadan.{{cite news |last=Deitch |first=Ian |date=1 July 2014 |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_ISRAEL_PALESTINIANS?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2014-07-01-04-25-41 |title=As Israel buries teens, airstrikes target Hamas |publisher=AP}}{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Ori |date=1 July 2014 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/01/us-palestinians-israel-idUSKBN0F521P20140701 |title=Israel mourns teenagers, strikes Hamas in Gaza |publisher=Reuters}} ====Day 20==== A Palestinian teenager was abducted from East Jerusalem and murdered. Israeli police located the body within hours, and arrested Israeli nationalist suspects several days later.{{cite news |title=Shin Bet forces arrest six in connection with Palestinian teens killing|url= http://www.israelnews.net/index.php/sid/223558111/scat/f81a4d9d561822ee/ht/Shin-Bet-forces-arrest-six-in-connection-with-Palestinian-teens-killing|accessdate=7 July 2014 |work=Israel News}} The [[kidnapping and murder of Mohammed Abu Khdeir]] was soundly denounced by all of the families of the Israeli kidnapping victims as well as by many Israeli governmental and non-governmental public figures. ===Week 4 and on (4 July and after)=== On 4 July, Israel stated it was searching for a third suspect, Husam Dofsh, absent from his home since the kidnapping. A relative, Jihad Dofsh, had blown himself up in a "work accident" in a Hamas explosives laboratory in Hebron, and one of Qawasmeh's relatives had died in the same incident.{{cite news |first1=Avi |last1=Issacharoff |first2=Adiv |last2=Sterman |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/third-hamas-operative-reported-missing-since-teens-kidnapping/ |title=Israel hunting third Hamas operative missing since night teens were killed |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=4 July 2014}} Husam Dofsh was arrested in a Hebron coffee-shop the following day, after phoning an Israeli news site to protest his innocence.{{cite news |first=Adiv |last=Sterman |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/suspected-accomplice-in-3-teens-killings-arrested/ |title=Suspected accomplice in 3 teens' killings arrested |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=6 July 2014}} For about two weeks in July, Israeli military preparations began for direct fighting inside of Gaza, whilst Hamas rocket fire into Israel took place.{{Cite news|url=http://jcpa.org/the-gaza-war-2014/|title=The Gaza War 2014|newspaper=Jerusalem Center For Public Affairs|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-13}} The military publicly announced on 17 July that it would go into Gaza, an intervention that caused at least 25 soldiers killed and scores injured on the Israeli side over the 20 to 21 July period. Public opinion in the nation is strongly divided, with, for example, the newspaper ''[[Haaretz]]'' editorializing that the "soft Gaza sand... could turn into quicksand" and warning about the "wholesale killing" of Palestinian civilians.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/israeli-mood-turns-dark-mounting-casualties-24652707|title=International|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=23 September 2014}} The campaign in the Gaza is referred to by Israel as [[Operation Protective Edge]]. On 20 August, Hamas official Saleh Al-'Arouri spoke at the conference of the [[International Union of Muslim Scholars]] in [[Istanbul]], where he said the group's military wing was responsible for the kidnapping of the three Israeli teens, saying it was an expression of popular will.Orlando Crowcroft [Hamas official: we were behind the kidnapping of three Israeli teenagers] [[The Guardian]] 21 August 2014. [[Khaled Mashal]], the Hamas leader, while recognizing that Hamas members were responsible, attempted to distance his organization from the killing two days later. Stating Hamas's opposition to killing civilians, he said the leadership had no advance knowledge of the abduction, which he regarded as a legitimate act by a frustrated people living under occupation, and that it had only learnt of its details from Israeli investigations.[http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.612039 Hamas: We wouldn't target civilians if we had better weapons,] [[Haaretz]] 23 August 2014. ==Aftermath== Following the kidnappings and the escalating firing of missiles by Palestinian militants towards civilians in southern Israel, Israel decides to embark on Operation Protective Edge. On 3 July 2014, the Israeli Air Force conducted 15 air strikes in Gaza directed at Hamas targets in response to a rocket attack from Palestinian militants. The previous night, fifteen Palestinians were injured in the IAF strikes and two buildings ruined{{cite news |title= Live updates, July 2: Israel strikes Gaza; Sderot hit by rocket |newspaper=Haaretz |date =3 July 2014|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.602557|accessdate=4 July 2014}}{{cite news |title=Buildings in ruins in Palestine after Israel's tit-for-tat airstrikes (photos, video) |publisher=RT|date=3 July 2014 |url=http://rt.com/news/170252-israel-palestinian-gaza-airstrikes/ |accessdate=4 July 2014}} [[Operation Protective Edge]], became a ground war on 8 July 2014, and is believed to have been triggered by the kidnapping and continuous indiscriminate Palestinian rocket fire on Israeli civilians. On 11 July 2014 it has been reported by the nonprofit news organization [[Washington Free Beacon]],{{cite web|last1=Kredo|first1=Adam|title=Congress to Offer $5 Million for Info on Hamas Kidnappers|url=http://freebeacon.com/national-security/congress-to-offer-5-million-for-info-on-hamas-kidnappers/|website=freebeacon.com|publisher=[[The Washington Free Beacon]]|accessdate=14 July 2014}} that a series of bills in the [[United States Senate]] and the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] was launched, attempting to solve the boys' murder, based on Yaakov Naftali Fraenkel's dual US-Israeli citizenship. The new legislation, if passed, would offer a $5 million reward for information on the abduction and murder.US representative [[Doug Lamborn]] said "Naftali Frenkel was an American citizen who was killed by terrorists and the United States should not rest until his killers are brought to justice (..) amazingly, the Obama administration still supports this terrorist Palestinian government, even after the death of an American citizen" {{cite web|last1=Dvorin|first1=Tova|title=US Bill to Offer $5 Million Reward for Tips on Teens' Abduction|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/182786|website=israelnationalnews.com/News/|publisher=Arutz Sheva|accessdate=14 July 2014}} ==Accusations of collective punishment== On Day 7, The Palestinian Authority declared that the Israeli [[modus operandi]], of clamping down on towns with closures and continual arrest of Hamas members, constituted [[collective punishment]].{{cite news |first=Marissa |last=Newsman |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/pa-accuses-israel-of-collective-punishment-in-west-bank/ |title=PA accuses Israel of 'collective punishment' in West Bank |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=19 June 2014}} [[Amnesty International]] issued a statement on 19 June calling both for the release of the Israeli youths, their humane treatment while being held, and for Israel to lift several measures it defined as collective punishment in violation of the [[Fourth Geneva Convention]] and [[customary international humanitarian law]]. According to ''[[The Economist]]'', "The Israeli security forces closed off the area around Hebron. Some 23,000 local Palestinians were barred from travelling to their jobs in Israel. A series of charitable organisations that used to be run by Hamas were closed down and a dairy, which employs hundreds of Palestinians, was demolished. Hebronites were prevented from travelling abroad."{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21606288-murder-three-kidnapped-israeli-youths-has-set-dangerous-new-spate |title=Israelis and Palestinians: A vicious circle speeds up again |newspaper=The Economist}} A number of scholars{{citation needed|reason=Scholars wouldn't overlook the wanton destruction of the dairy|date=July 2014}} rejected the claim that Operation Brother's Keeper constitutes collective punishment under international law: * Robbie Sabel, a professor of [[international law]] at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] and a former legal adviser to [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)|Israel's Foreign Ministry]], stated that Israel's actions cannot be considered collective punishment as they are aimed exclusively at finding the kidnapped teenagers and weakening the terrorist organizations behind their abduction and that in a search for kidnapped civilians, the arrests of members affiliated with the organization responsible for the kidnapping is legitimate.{{cite news|last=Ahren|first=Raphael|title=Is Israel's operation to find kidnapped teens a war crime?|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/is-israels-operation-to-find-kidnapped-teens-a-war-crime |accessdate=27 June 2014|work=The Times of Israel|date=23 June 2014}} * Eugene Kontorovich, international law professor at [[Northwestern University]] and Hebrew University has stated, "rounding up suspects, or potential witnesses, is not punishment, but rather rudimentary investigative process; especially when the crime is thought to be committed by a complex terror organization, the number of potential witnesses is high." Kontorovich cited as an example that police often arrest members of a gang after a crime to further investigate the perpetrators or criminal acts. ==Speculations on kidnapping motives== In an address to the [[World Economic Forum]] in May 2013, Mahmoud Abbas stated that a primary concern of Palestinian society is the approximately 5,000 Palestinian prisoners in Israeli prisons. The problem could be handled by negotiated concessions or by abductions, used to get them back. This has been called his [[Prisoner's dilemma]], and he asked if Israel wanted more Shalit kidnapping cases, a practice he maintained went against the grain of Palestinian culture. Hamas quickly challenged his statement as 'unpatriotic'.{{Cite news |first=Elhanan |last=Miller |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/mahmoud-abbass-prisoners-dilemma/ |title=Mahmoud Abbas's prisoner dilemma |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=17 June 2014|accessdate= 4 July 2014}} Some 300 prisoners are on a hunger strike against the [[Palestinian prisoners in Israel|Israeli practice of holding Palestinians]] in [[Administrative detention]] without charges for six months or more.{{cite news |first=Christa Case |last=Bryant |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2014/0614/Why-were-kidnapped-Israeli-teens-hitchhiking-in-the-West-Bank-video |title=Why were kidnapped Israeli teens hitchhiking in the West Bank? |newspaper=The [[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=14 June 2014}} Many Palestinians support the kidnapping of Israeli soldiers and civilians in order to obtain the release of these prisoners.{{cite news |first=Yusri |last=al-Jammal |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/06/15/uk-palestinian-israel-idUKKBN0EP0DX20140615 |title=Fearing three teens abducted, Israel escalates West Bank search with Abbas help |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=15 June 2014 |place=UK}} In 2011, Israel released more than a thousand Palestinians in detention, many convicted by Israeli courts for lethal attacks,{{cite news |first=Isabel |last=Kershner |author-link=Isabel Kershner |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/17/world/middleeast/abduction-of-young-israeli-hitchhikers-spurs-debate-on-conduct.html |title=Abduction of Young Israeli Hitchhikers Spurs Debate on Conduct |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=16 June 2014}} [[Gilad Shalit prisoner exchange|in exchange for Gilad Shalit]], an Israeli soldier kidnapped by Palestinian militants. Some months before the 2014 incident, an 18-page manual on abduction techniques was published by Hamas. Entitled "Guide for the Kidnapper", it provided an operational guide that outlined the use of pistols with silencers, the use of backup cars, the choice of conducting the abductions on rainy days, a command of Hebrew, the renting of hideouts in areas to avoid arousing suspicions and suggestions to refrain from announcing the outcome of the kidnapping until the victims were secured in a safe house.{{cite news |first=Zvi |last=Bar'el |url=http://www.haaretz.com/.premium-1.598993 |title=Egypt cooperating with Israeli search efforts for kidnapped teens, while Hamas faces catch-22 |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=16 June 2014}} Fatah is reported to believe that [[Ismail Haniyeh]] has given the go-ahead to Palestinian cells to pursue such tactics in order to "bring the prisoners affair to an end".{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} The difficulty confronting the [[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades]], which has an ongoing debate on the issue, is the coordination between the PNA and Israeli security services, which makes executing such operations difficult. Several prior incidents, such as the killings of Givati soldier Gal "Gavriel" Kobi and Baruch Mizrahi, a police intelligence officer, displayed exceptional, high-level skills, strict compartmentalization, and careful preparations for an escape route, features shared by the kidnapping. These elements resemble the carefully planned abductions of IDF soldiers by [[Hezbollah]] on Israel's northern border. Israel said that the IDF and the Shin Bet have foiled between 54{{cite news |first=Asmaa |last=al-Ghoul |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/06/19/could-kidnapping-of-israeli-boys-lead-to-intifada |title=Could Kidnapping of Israeli Boys Lead to Intifada? |newspaper=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |date=19 June 2014 |quote=Ya'alon added that in 2013, more than 30 kidnapping attempts were foiled, and another 14 attempts since the beginning of this year.}} and 64 kidnapping plots since 2013. The PA said it had foiled 43 of them. The high success rate (95%) in blocking such plots is due to the very close cooperation between the security forces of both sides.{{cite news |first=Amos |last=Harel |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2014/06/26/bibi_and_the_lost_boys_netanyahu_israel_kidnapped_teenagers_abbas |title=Bibi and the Lost Boys |newspaper=[[Foreign Policy]] |date=26 June 2014 |quote=Since the end of the Second Intifada, around 2005, Israelis have grown to expect a success rate of almost 95 percent in stopping terrorist attacks before they occur. Most terror suspects in the West Bank are either arrested before they manage to do anything, or immediately thereafter. A major reason for this success has been the very close cooperation between Israel and Palestinian security officials – a relationship both sides prefer to keep as low-profile as possible.}} Hamas has put considerable effort into kidnapping attempts through its large network.{{cite news |first1=William |last1=Booth |first2=Ruth |last2=Eglash |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/israel-goes-after-hamas-in-west-bank-in-wake-of-teens-abduction/2014/06/18/d3576d56-adc5-4027-9a0b-90e570346543_story.html |title=Israel clamps down on Hamas in West Bank after abduction of three Jewish teenagers |newspaper=The [[Washington Post]] |date=18 June 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.eureporter.co/world/2014/06/16/palestinians-voice-support-for-kidnapping-of-3-israeli-teens-by-hamas-terrorists/ |title=Palestinians voice support for kidnapping of three Israeli teens by Hamas terrorists |newspaper=EU reporter |date=16 June 2014}} A week into the search for the missing youth, Avi Issacharoff cast doubts on the premise for West Bank operations, which in his view 'targeted the weak'—since Hamas has neither a large or strong presence there—and argued that the operational order, if there was one, came from either Gaza, or abroad, perhaps Ankara-based deportee Saleh al-Arouri, or [[Khaled Mashaal]], who appeared to hint a month earlier in replying to a letter from an imprisoned Hamas leader, after Netanyahu reneged on releasing [[2013–14 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks|a fourth group of Palestinian prisoners]],{{cite news |first=Amir |last=Oren |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/.premium-1.600055 |title=West Bank kidnapping exposes Israel's disjointed security establishment |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=20 June 2014}} that the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades would be his reply. Issacharoff concluded however that, "There isn't a smoking gun to prove the Hamas leadership is complicit in the kidnapping."{{cite news |first=Avi |last=Issacharoff |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/a-week-of-raids-and-arrests-but-no-hard-lead-to-the-kidnappers/ |title=A week of raids and arrests, but no hard lead to the kidnappers |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=20 June 2014}} On 20 August, a Hamas official identified the West Bank Qawasmeh clan, a Hamas ally, for the kidnapping of the three Israeli teens and shared their motives. Saleh Al-'Arouri of the Hamas leadership delivered an address on behalf of [[Khaled Mashal]] at the conference of the [[International Union of Muslim Scholars]] in [[Istanbul]]. In it he said: "Our goal was to ignite an [[wiktionary:Intifada|intifada]] in the West Bank and Jerusalem, as well as within the 1948 borders... Your brothers in the [[Al-Qassam Brigades]] carried out this operation to support their imprisoned brothers, who were on a hunger strike... The [[mujahideen]] captured these settlers in order to have a swap deal."{{cite web|url=http://www.memritv.org/clip/en/4437.htm|title=Hamas Leadership Acknowledges Responsibility for Kidnapping Three Israeli Teens|publisher=}} ==Hitchhiking debate in Israel== As events unfolded, the dangerous nature of hitchhiking in what Israelis refer to as "the territories" prompted a debate, regarded by some in the settler and religious Zionist communities as a kind of [[victim blaming]],{{cite news |first=Anshel |last=Pfeffer |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/.premium-1.598878 |title=Abductions won't stop settlers from hitchhiking |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=15 June 2014}} about the practice of hitching rides on roads in the [[Palestinian territories]], widely regarded as a cavalier and irresponsible habit for the costs involved in redeeming anyone who is captured. The normal Israeli practice is one where drivers pull up, declaring their destination, and, by their accent, allowing potential hikers at ''trempiada'' (hitchhiking stations) an opportunity to examine the cues, before they accept or decline a lift. Such hitchhiking has long been a hallowed method of travel among Israelis,{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} but as abductions and killings of hitchhikers, mainly IDF soldiers, began to take root in the 1980s,{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} [[Kidnapping of Nachshon Wachsman|one incident in October 1994]] led to the passage of regulations that forbade military personnel from resorting to this method of travel.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} To hammer the message home, recruits doing basic training are required now to view [[snuff film]]s that highlight the dangers, and military police "abduct" and punish recruits who do not take it seriously. Israeli governments have not regulated civilian recourse to hitchhiking, and laws delegate responsibility to parents, expecting them to advise their children. The practice however remains widespread among the ''[[Modern Orthodox Judaism|dati leumi]]'' community of [[Religious Zionism|religious Zionists]] for several reasons: many of them, as in this case, have children boarding in West Bank settlements, where public transport facilities are poor.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} ''Haaretz'' reported that for mitzvah-observant adolescents, it is "a rite of passage, a way of life, a declaration of independence and of ownership of the land". Retired Brigadier General, Nitzan Nuriel, a former counter-terrorism officer in the Prime Minister's Office, declared on Israeli television that hitchhiking had an ideological edge: it made a statement about who owns the territory. ==Reactions== ==={{Flag |Israel}}=== An Israeli government official stated to ''[[Reuters]]'' news agency that Israel was looking to use the search as a pretext for a wider crackdown on Hamas and were looking into the legal aspects of deporting Hamas leaders from the West Bank.{{cite news|last=Sawafta |first=Ali |title=Israel expands West Bank hunt for missing teens, Palestinian killed|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/16/us-palestinian-israel-idUSKBN0ER05F20140616|accessdate=16 June 2014|publisher=Reuters}} A Hebrew-language Facebook page calling on PM Netanyahu to assume his responsibilities and requesting that a Palestinian "terrorist" be executed every hour until the three youths are restored to their families, gained 10,000 thumb-ups within hours.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=705004 |title=Thousands join online campaign to kill Palestinian 'terrorists' |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |newspaper=[[Maariv]] |date=15 June 2014}}{{cite news |last=Dearden |first=Lizzie|title=Facebook campaign calls on Israelis to kill a Palestinian terrorist every hour until missing teenagers found|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/online-campaign-calling-on-israelis-to-kill-a-palestinian-terrorist-every-hour-until-missing-teenagers-found-9540604.html |accessdate=16 June 2014|work=The Independent}} With a perception in Israel, expressed by Thane Rosenbaum, that the sympathy long lavished on Israel is dwindling,{{cite news |first=Thane |last=Rosenbaum |url=http://www.haaretz.com/opinion/.premium-1.600583 |title=The world's cruel indifference to Israel's plight |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=23 June 2014}} the government stepped up [[hasbara]] efforts abroad, especially in Brazil where the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] has dominated the world's attention. An aircraft trailed a #BringBackOurBoys banner along a Rio de Janeiro beach. The families of the missing boys went to Geneva to address the [[United Nations Human Rights Council|UN's Human Rights Council]].{{cite news |first=Itamar |last=Eichner |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4533679,00.html |title=Missing teens' families to address UN Human Rights Council |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=23 June 2014}} * On television, Netanyahu declared that "Anyone trying to harm Israeli civilians will be harmed in return." * Israel's Economic Minister [[Naftali Bennett]] said Israel will make membership of Hamas a 'ticket to hell', branding it one 'of the most "lethal, barbaric organizations in the world". Both the PA and Hamas, he affirmed, formed a 'complete culture where Israel is [perceived as] Satan.'{{cite news |first=Gavriel |last=Fiske |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/bennett-promises-ticket-to-hell-for-hamas-members/ |title=Bennett promises 'ticket to hell' for Hamas members |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=17 June 2014}} * 15 June. Pure and simple,'][[The Independent]] 2 September 2014. ====Social media in Israel==== [[File:Bring Back our Boys 2014.jpg|thumb|"Bring back our boys" on Jerusalem bus, June 2014.]] A [[social media]] campaign was started soon after the kidnapping advocating for the safe return of the teens under the [[hashtag]] #BringBackOurBoys. According to Robert Mackey, the campaign was initiated by a "group of Israelis trained to promote their country online"{{cite news|last1=Mackay|first1=Robert|title=Israelis Start #BringBackOurBoys Campaign|url=http://news.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/06/17/israelis-start-bringbackourboys-campaign/ |accessdate=21 June 2014|work=The New York Times}}{{cite news |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-2659880/Israel-leader-wants-world-pressure-Palestinians.html |title=Israel leader wants world pressure on Palestinians |newspaper=The [[Daily Mail]] |date=17 June 2014}} The campaign's label attempted to make the link between the then-recent #BringBackOurGirls campaign following the [[Chibok schoolgirl kidnapping]] in Nigeria. One of the organizers stated the social media effort "is simply a cry out to the world to bring those boys back", adding that "We're only trying to do whatever we can to help the international community to put pressure to release those kids". On 15 June, around 25,000 people gathered for a prayer at the [[Western Wall]] for the release of the kidnapped teenagers.{{cite news |last1=Megnazi |first1=Avail |last2=Morag |first2=Gilad |date=16 June 2014 |title=Rabbi Lau: Israeli nation will never break |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4530769,00.html |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |accessdate=16 June 2014}} ====Violent Israeli reactions==== On the night of 1 July a Palestinian family registered a complaint at police concerning an attempt to kidnap their child, 10-year-old Moussa Zalum, on [[Shuafat|Shu'fat]]'s main street in Jerusalem. At the time, they reported, he was walking with his mother and brother when a car stopped and people tried to pull him into the vehicle. The child managed to wriggle free, and the car sped off.{{cite news |url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/headlines-breaking-stories/244703/burned-body-of-arab-found-in-jerusalem-forest.html |title=Burned Body of Arab Found in Jerusalem Forest |newspaper=[[Yeshiva World News]] |date=3 July 2014}} After the bodies of the three boys were found, settlers attacks on Palestinians in the West Bank were reported. Settlers from [[Tel Rumeida]] in Hebron were in the streets, attacking Palestinians and internationals. The Border Police stormed the hill towards the gathered crowd of Palestinians and internationals, exploded a sound grenade and injured a Palestinian in the following clash.{{cite news |url=http://www.cpt.org/cptnet/2014/07/01/al-khalil-hebron-cpt-palestine-responds-incidents-occurring-after-teenagers%E2%80%99-bodie |place=Al-Khalil (Hebron) |title=CPT Palestine responds to incidents occurring after teenagers' bodies discovered |publisher=CPT |date=1 July 2014}} {{main|Kidnapping and murder of Mohammed Abu Khdeir}} On 2 July a 16-year-old Palestinian from [[Shu'fat camp]], Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was killed; preliminary results from the autopsy suggest he was burnt alive. The boy's family believes the killing to be an act of revenge from Jewish settlers for the murder of the three Israeli teenagers.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28174519|title=Palestinian Mohammad Abu Khdair 'was burned alive'}} Netanyahu urged a swift inquiry into the "reprehensible murder" and called on people to respect the rule of law.{{cite news |title=Palestinians say Israeli extremists killed teen |url=http://westhawaiitoday.com/news/nation-world-news/palestinians-say-israeli-extremists-killed-teen |newspaper=West Hawai'i Today}} On the evening of 3 July, Palestinians of Shu'fat reported to the Israeli police that four settlers from [[Pisgat Zeev]] had attempted to kidnap a 7-year-old local child, and had fled on being thwarted.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=709927 |title=Locals: Settlers try to kidnap 7-year-old in Beit Hanina |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |date=4 July 2014}} On Friday Palestinians of [[Osarin]] near [[Nablus]] in the [[West Bank]] complained that one of them, 22-year-old Tariq Ziad Zuhdi Adeli, had been sprayed with a gas by settlers, abducted in a car, taken outside the village and then sustained injuries from a hatchet attack to his legs.{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=710084 |title=Locals: Settlers 'abduct, attack' Palestinian near Nablus |publisher=Ma'an News Agency |date=5 July 2014}} Three days later, a video was aired, that appeared as the beating up of 15-year-old American citizen Tariq Abu Khdeir by Israeli security forces. Tariq, a second-cousin of murdered Mohammed Abu Khdeir, is a student who attends Universal Academy of Florida high school in Tampa, Florida.{{cite web|url=http://www.wtsp.com/story/news/local/2014/07/05/tampa-teenager-beaten-and-jailed-in-israel/12238105/|title=Tampa teen beaten, jailed in Jerusalem |publisher=WTSP |date=5 July 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/israel-palestine-teenager-beaten-police-video-jerusalem |title=Video shows Israeli police beating Palestinian teenager |date=5 July 2014 |publisher=[[Channel 4]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posttv/national/us-teen-allegedly-beaten-detained-in-israeli-prison/2014/07/05/4a1259cc-0470-11e4-ae91-d5e5645b17c1_video.html |title=US teen allegedly beaten, detained in Israeli prison |date=5 July 2014 |newspaper=The [[Washington Post]]}} Israeli authorities then detained Tariq. The US State Department has called for "a speedy, transparent and credible investigation and full accountability for any excessive use of force".{{cite web|last1=Psaki |first1=Jen|title=Detention of Tariq Khdeir|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2014/07/228774.htm|website=Press Releases: July 2014|publisher=US Department of State|accessdate=5 July 2014}} Israeli Border Police started an official investigation on 5 July.{{cite news|title=Beaten Palestinian youth is US citizen, cousin of murdered kidnap victim |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.603184 |accessdate=5 July 2014 |work=Haaretz|date=5 July 2014}} ==={{PSE}}=== Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas, defying widespread popular Palestinian support for the kidnapping as a means of securing the release of [[Palestinian prisoners in Israel|Palestinians held in Israeli jails]], criticized the action, saying the youths must be returned,{{cite news|last=Dónzis|first=Aron|title=Abbas: Kidnapped youths 'must be returned'|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/abbas-kidnapped-youths-must-be-returned |accessdate=20 June 2014|work=The Times of Israel|date=18 June 2014}} and that [[Palestinian Authority]] security was cooperating with Israel to try to locate them.{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Elhanan|title=Cooperation with PA on kidnapping 'professional,' army official says|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/cooperation-with-pa-on-kidnapping-professional-army-official-says|accessdate=20 June 2014|work=The Times of Israel|date=17 June 2014}} Abbas' office released a statement condemning the kidnapping and the Israeli response of raids and arrests. At US urging, Abbas was working closely with Israel to coordinate the search for the teens.{{cite news|last=Booth|first=William|title=Palestinian President Abbas condemns kidnapping of Israeli teens|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/palestinian-president-abbas-condemns-kidnapping-of-israeli-teens/2014/06/16/477fa638-f557-11e3-a606-946fd632f9f1_story.html |accessdate=16 February 2014|work=The Washington Post}} A PA spokesman stated that holding Palestinian authorities responsible for kidnappings in Area C of the West Bank, where Israel exercises full military control and prohibits a Palestinian police presence places the PA in an impossible position. The Palestinian Authority's official newspaper marked the kidnapping with a cartoon that spoofed the World Cup logo. Three hands hold the globe in the FIFA World Cup logo, but in Al-Hayat Al-Jadida, three hands held small helpless figures with their hands up in surrender. While the World Cup logo says "Brazil" under it, the spoof says Khalil, the Arabic name for Hebron, a city near the site of the kidnapping.{{cite news |url=http://www.jewishnews.net.au/pa-cartoon-glorifies-kidnapping/35689 |title=PA cartoon glorifies kidnapping |newspaper=[[The Australian Jewish News]] |date=19 June 2014}} A cartoon on a Fatah Facebook page presented the three kidnapped Israeli teenagers as rats caught on three hooks on a fishing rod. Each rat was emblazoned with a Star of David, and the title of the cartoon read "Masterstroke". A picture on the same Facebook page showed a hand with words written on three of the fingers. Read in succession they said: "Three Shalits, long live Palestine".{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/mahmoud-abbass-prisoners-dilemma/ |title=Mahmoud Abbas's prisoner dilemma,' |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=17 June 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/181726 |title=Sick: Fatah Posts Cartoon Mocking Kidnapped Teens as 'Rats' |newspaper=[[Israel National News]] |date=15 June 2014}} Hamas spokesmen Sami Abu Zuhri and Fawzi Barhoum criticized the PNA collaboration with Israel to track down the culprits,{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Elhanan|title=Hamas and Fatah clash over conciliatory Abbas speech|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/hamas-and-fatah-clash-over-conciliatory-abbas-speech|accessdate=20 June 2014|work=The Times of Israel|date=19 June 2014}} and Barhoum called the kidnappers "heroes".{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4530169,00.html |title=Hamas angered by PA help in search for missing teens |agency=Reuters |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=14 June 2014}} In social media, many Palestinians criticized what they see as the strong emphasis placed by Israel on the teenagers' disappearance to the detriment of Palestinian suffering, citing the case of two Palestinian boys shot dead by Israelis at a protest in [[Beitunia killings|Beitunia]] during a [[Nakba Day]] protest on 15 May 2014. On [[Twitter]], in response to the IDF campaign, Palestinian sympathizers appropriated the hashtag as their own, drawing attention to both Palestinian prisoners in Israeli goals and Palestinian children killed by Israeli actions. One mentioned 5,271 Palestinian political prisoners, 192 administrative detainees, 17 women and 196 children.{{cite news |first=Howard |last=Koplowitz |url=http://m.ibtimes.com/bringbackourboys-idf-hashtag-sparks-palestinian-outrage-twitter-1601370 |title=#BringBackOurBoys IDF Hashtag Sparks Palestinian Outrage On Twitter |newspaper=The [[International Business Times]] |date=14 June 2014}} Senior Hamas and Islamic Jihad officials have stated that kidnapping Israeli soldiers and settlers is the only route to obtain the release of Palestinian prisoners.{{cite news |last =Harel|first =Amos|title=Missing teens: Time is not on their side|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/1.598633|accessdate=16 June 2014|work=Haaretz |date=13 June 2014|ref=Hz}} Palestinian [[Fatah]] and Hamas activists called on Palestinian shopkeepers and businessmen in Hebron, via Facebook, Twitter and other social media, to destroy any CCTV footage that could be used by Israel to help locate the teens. |url=http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Palestinian-activists-call-for-destruction-of-CCTV-footage-in-attempt-to-frustrate-IDF-search-359321 |title=Palestinian activists call for destruction of CCTV These boys were in the prime of their lives and have been the victim of a horrific crime. The government of the Netherlands hopes that their killers will be apprehended soon and brought to justice." * {{Flag |European Union}}'s ambassador to Israel tweeted that he was "deeply concerned" about the events and was hoping for the safe return of the teens. [[Catherine Ashton]]'s [[High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy|office]] condemned the kidnapping after five days, in the wake of Israeli official expressions of disappointment.{{cite news |first=Herb |last=Keinon |url=http://www.jpost.com/Pillar-of-Defense/After-five-days-EU-condemns-kidnapping-of-Israeli-teens-359616 |title=After five days, EU condemns kidnapping of Israeli teens |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=17 June 2014}} On 28 June the EU reiterated its call for the safe return of the youths. It regretted the increasing violence, particularly the killing of several Palestinians, and called on Israel to only use [[Proportionality (law)|proportionate means]] in its search. It praised the Palestinian security services for their help in searching for the abductees, and condemned Hamas for praising the kidnapping.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/eu-urges-israeli-restraint-in-search-for-abductees/ |title=EU urges Israeli restraint in search for abductees |newspaper=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=29 June 2014}} After the dead bodies of the three teenagers were found, the EU's ambassador to Israel, Lars Faaborg-Andersen, tweeted that he sent condolences to the Israeli government on the "despicable" murders, "with hope that perpetrators are soon arrested". * {{Flag |Egypt}}'s foreign ministry released a statement asking [[Israel]] to stop what it called "its collective punishment of the Palestinian people", after it bombed dozens of sites in the Gaza Strip a day after the bodies of three missing Israeli teenagers were found. Egypt urged the Israeli forces to practice restraint and allow the Palestinian authorities to take on its responsibility in tracking the culprits, it also renewed its condemnation for all forms of violence that cause the death of civilians on both sides.{{cite news |first=Herb |last=Keinon |url=http://en.aswatmasriya.com/news/view.aspx?id=90f82c4f-be03-4d87-80f4-937588c3fed4 |title=Egypt urges Israel to stop collective punishment of Palestinians |publisher=[[Aswat Masriya]] |date=1 June 2014}} * {{Flag |Colombia}}'s [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Colombia)|Foreign Ministry]] released a statement condemning the assassination of the 3 teenagers that had previously been kidnapped on 12 June while on the same statement declaring the murder as an act of terrorism. Colombia expressed its condolences to the families of the victims and called to "reflect, and ponder on this difficult moments, in accordance to international rights."{{cite web|url=http://www.cancilleria.gov.co/newsroom/publiques/2014-07-01/9500|title=Cancillería expresa enérgica condena por el asesinato de los tres jóvenes israelíes |language=es |publisher=cancilleria.gov.co |date=1 July 2014 |accessdate=11 July 2014}} * {{Flag |Nigeria}}'s President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] wrote to Netanyahu: "... I assure you that we are in solidarity with you, as we believe that any act of terrorism against any nation or group is an act against our common humanity. We unequivocally condemn this dastardly act, and demand that the children are released unconditionally by their abductors."{{cite news|last=Lidman |first=Melanie |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/nigerian-leader-decries-dastardly-kidnapping-of-teens/ |title=Nigerian leader decries 'dastardly' kidnapping of teens |work=The Times of Israel |date=12 May 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2014}} * {{Flag |Holy See}} The Vatican condemned the killing of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank as a "hideous and unacceptable crime" and an obstacle to peace, calling the news of the deaths "terrible and dramatic".{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/30/us-palestinians-vatican-idUSKBN0F52FU20140630 |title=Vatican calls Israeli teenagers deaths hideous, threat to peace |publisher=Reuters |date=30 June 2014}} * [[Quartet on the Middle East|Quartet]] envoy [[Tony Blair]] posted a tweet saying that the abduction and killing of "these three young people was a heinous and wicked thing to do". * Foreign Minister Avigdor Liberman said that [[Germany]], France, Britain, [[Belgium]], [[Bulgaria]] and [[Norway]] all condemned the kidnapping of {{Infobox character | name = Aaron Doral
Number Five | series = [[Battlestar Galactica]] | image = BattlestarGalactica 1x06 Litmus.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | first = [[Battlestar Galactica (2003 miniseries)|Miniseries]] | last = ''[[Battlestar Galactica: The Plan]]'' | portrayer = [[Matthew Bennett]] | species = [[Cylon (Battlestar Galactica)#Humanoid Cylons|Humanoid Cylon]] | gender = [[Male]] }} '''Aaron Doral''' ('''Number Five''') is a [[fictional character]] from the reimagined ''[[Battlestar Galactica (re-imagining)|Battlestar Galactica]]'' series. ==The first Doral== Prior to [[Destruction of the Twelve Colonies|the Fall]], Aaron Doral is the civilian [[Public Relations Officer]] aboard the battlestar ''Galactica''. During the events of the [[Battlestar Galactica (miniseries)|miniseries]], [[Gaius Baltar]]'s attention is drawn by his apparational [[Number Six (Battlestar Galactica)|Number Six]] to a device in the ''Galactica'''s [[Combat Information Center|CIC]]. Six convinces Baltar that it is a Cylon device and that he can do nothing about it without revealing his connection to her. Panicking, Baltar wonders aloud whether Doral (whose movements are relatively unsupervised) could be a Cylon agent, which Six denies. Baltar accuses Doral anyway, and the [[Executive Officer|XO]], Col. [[Saul Tigh]], throws Doral in the brig. Doral emphatically denies being a Cylon, but after Cdr. [[William Adama]] is forced to kill [[Leoben Conoy|Number Two]], Baltar frames Doral with what he claims is a "Cylon test." Unwilling to risk the chance that Baltar is right, Adama abandons Doral (presumably to die) at the [[Ragnar Anchorage]] when the ragtag fleet leaves the Cyrannus system forever. The audience swiftly learns, however, that Baltar was (unwittingly) correct: Soon after the ''Galactica'' leaves Ragnar, Doral is rescued by several Twos, Fives, Sixes, and at least one [[Number Eight (Battlestar Galactica)|Eight]]. ==Number Five== Throughout the show, the Colonial authorities tend to use "Doral" and "Leoben" as generic terms for Numbers Two and Five respectively. A second Five detonates a suicide bomb in the episode [[Litmus (Battlestar Galactica)|Litmus]], and many more Fives appear operating Cylon baseships and the Cylon occupations of the Colonies and New Caprica. The Fives side with the Ones and Fours in the brief [[Cylon Civil War]]. ==Personality== The Fives have an unassuming, "average" appearance in order to better blend into the background. Several Fives appear to have positions of authority among the Cylons, acting as an overseer. For example, the project to have an Eight seduce [[Karl Agathon|Karl "Helo" Agathon]] is supervised by a Five who monitors and directs the situation with apparent curiosity. Others, however, seem to have below-average intelligence: In "[[Battlestar Galactica: The Plan|The Plan]]," a [[John Cavil|Number One]] berates a confused Doral copy (wearing clothing nearly identical to the first copy encountered by the Colonials) for his lack of disguise and caution while wandering the ''Galactica''. A later scene shows a small group of Doral copies assigned to menial labor disposing of masses of human corpses on occupied Caprica, doing work they complain is below them and should be handled by Centurions. The Fives seem more fanatical and compassionless than the other humanoid Cylons, excluding the Number Ones. They are the only humanoid Cylon model never shown in any kind of romantic or sexual relationship. They discuss the genocide of mankind in calm, functional abstractions, and unhesitatingly resort to violence.[[Occupation (Battlestar Galactica)|Occupation]]; [[Litmus (Battlestar Galactica)|Litmus]]. In "[[Torn(Battlestar Galactica)|Torn]]" a Number Eight accuses Doral of "barely even being able to say [God's] name," suggesting that the Fives' pieties are a sham. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://en.battlestarwikiclone.org/wiki/Number_Five Number Five] at the Battlestar Wiki * [http://www.syfy.com/battlestar/cast/doral Number Five] at Syfy {{Battlestar Galactica characters}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Doral, Aaron}} [[Category:Cylons]] [[Category:Fictional secret agents and spies]] [[Category:Fictional cyborgs]] [[Category:Fictional clones]] [[Category:Fictional suicides]] [[Category:Fictional characters with death or rebirth abilities]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2003]]

'''Ambiguous loss''' is a loss that occurs without closure [[Ambiguity|or understanding]].<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0674028589 | title=Ambiguous Loss: Learning to Live with Unresolved Grief | publisher=Harvard University Press | author=Boss, Pauline | year=2000 | isbn=978-0674003811}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/15/fashion/exit-left-wordlessly.html?pagewanted=all | title=Exit Left, Wordlessly | work=The New York Times | date=January 12, 2012 | accessdate=25 July 2013 | author=Ball, Aimee Lee}}</ref> This kind of loss leaves a person searching for answers, and thus complicates and delays the process of [[Grief|grieving]], and often results in unresolved grief. Some examples are [[infertility]], [[termination of pregnancy]], disappearance of a family member,<ref>Beam, C., & Dudly, D. (2014, August 1). [http://www.aarp.org/home-family/friends-family/info-2014/loss-of-loved-ones-grief.html Living With A Loved One's Disappearance]. AARP The Magazine.</ref> death of an ex-spouse, a family member being physically alive but in a state of cognitive decline due to [[Alzheimer's disease]] or [[dementia]], etc.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.indiana.edu/~famlygrf/units/ambiguous.html | title=Ambiguous Loss and Disenfranchised Grief | publisher=Indiana University | date=February 1996 | accessdate=25 July 2013 | author=Gilbert, Kathleen R.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/brierdudley/2008/05/shankar_sastry_tenacious.html | title=From the Jim Gray tribute: Searching the sea, coping with ambiguity and the Microsoft discount | publisher=The Seattle Times | date=May 31, 2008 | accessdate=26 July 2013 | author=Dudley, Brier}}</ref> An ambiguous loss can be categorized into two types of loss, physical or psychological.<ref name=Boss.1>{{cite journal|last1=Boss|first1=Pauline|title=The Trauma and Complicated Grief of Ambiguous Loss|journal=Pastoral Psychology|date=April 2010|volume=59|issue=2|page=138}}</ref> Physical loss and psychological loss differ in terms of what is being grieved for, the loss of the physical body, or the psychological mind. Experiencing an ambiguous loss can lead to personal questions, such as, "Am I still married to my missing spouse?," or "Am I still a child to a parent who no longer remembers me?".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Boss|first1=Pauline|title=Insights: ambiguous loss: living with frozen grief.|journal=The Harvard mental health letter / from Harvard Medical School|date=November 1999|volume=16|issue=5|pages=4–6|pmid=10521908}}</ref> Since the grief process in an ambiguous loss is halted, it is harder to cope or move on to acceptance from the type of loss experienced. There are various types of grief that can occur due to the type of ambiguity experienced and corresponding therapy techniques to address the certain types of grief. The overall goal of therapy to cope with ambiguous loss is to overcome the trauma associated with it and restoring resilience.<ref name=GestaltRoos>{{cite journal|last1=Roos|first1=Susan|title=Chronic Sorrow and Ambiguous Loss: Gestalt Methods for Coping with Grief|journal=Gestalt Review|date=2013|volume=17|issue=3|pages=229-239}}</ref>
== Types of ambiguous loss ==
An ambiguous loss can be physical or psychological in nature.
===Physical loss=== A physical ambiguous loss means that the body of a loved one is no longer around, such as a missing person or unrecovered body from war, but is still remembered psychologically due to the chance of coming back, for example in missing person cases.<ref name=Boss.1 /> A physical ambiguous loss can occur across generations, such as the families of victims of the holocaust, and can cause as traumatic distress as [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Boss|first1=Pauline|title=The Trauma and Complicated Grief of Ambiguous Loss|journal=Pastoral Psychology|date=April 2010|volume=59|issue=2|page=139}}</ref>
===Psychological loss=== The second type of ambiguous loss is where a person is still physically there, but is psychologically absent.<ref name=Boss.1 /> This happens in cases where the brain is affected, therefore affecting the behavior or well being of the individual. Psychological ambiguous loss does not just occur to family and friends of the person affected. Psychological loss can happen personally in terms of one losing sense of who they are. This can stem from having a traumatic brain injury and not knowing who they are, causing a lost feeling and uncertain identity issues.<ref name=MTBI>{{cite journal|last1=Landau|first1=Judith|last2=Hissett|first2=Jennifer|title=Mild traumatic brain injury: Impact on identity and ambiguous loss in the family.|journal=Families, Systems, & Health|date=March 2008|volume=26|issue=1|page=74|doi=10.1037/1091-7527.26.1.69}}</ref>
==Grieving process== The grieving process for an ambiguous loss differs from regular [[mourning]] in unable to gain closure due to unresolved grief.<ref name="Boss book">{{cite book|last1=Boss|first1=Pauline|title=Ambiguous Loss: Learning to Live with Unresolved Grief|date=November 1, 2000|publisher=Harvard University Press|pages=9-10}}</ref> In cases of a psychological ambiguous loss, the grieving process can be especially difficult because of the inability to accept or admit that there is a problem and cannot confront their situation in the first place in order to deal with the problem.<ref name=Resilience>{{cite journal|last1=Abrams|first1=Madeleine Seifter|title=Resilience in Ambiguous Loss.|journal=American Journal of Psychotherapy|date=Spring 2001|volume=55|issue=2|page=284}}</ref> One key factor in getting over an ambiguous loss is resilience. In the normal grieving process, people obtain [[Closure (psychology)|closure]] after dealing with a loss. In an ambiguous loss, closure does not exist, and should not be sought after in this case.<ref name=Boss.1 /> ===Resilience=== [[Psychological resilience|Resilience]] and hope are important in the case of an ambiguous loss because paired together, they are able to allow the individual to come to terms with the loss and continue moving forward in life.<ref name="Boss book" /><ref name=Resilience/> Some ways to tell that one is resilient in a case with ambiguous loss is actively seek out help when they know it is needed.<ref name=Walsh>{{cite book|last1=Walsh|first1=Froma|title=Strengthening Family Resilience|date=September 25, 1998|publisher=Guilford|location=New York}}</ref> Uncontrollable factors such as culture, age, socioeconomic status, and genetics are all factors that contribute to resilience.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Boss|first1=Pauline|title=Loss, Trauma, and Resilience: Therapeutic Work with Ambiguous Loss|date=2006|publisher=WW Norton & Company|page=3}}</ref> Trauma and ambiguous loss often co-exist together and if the trauma is not dealt with it can trigger unresolved emotions.<ref name=GestaltRoos/> Therapy will address a case of ambiguous loss by restoring resilience, and reconnecting with the loss and the relationship with whom the loss is associated.<ref name=GestaltRoos/>
===Three types of grief=== The difference between regular grief and grief from an ambiguous loss is the type of loss creates the type of grief experienced.<ref name=ClosureMyth>{{cite journal|last1=Boss|first1=Pauline|last2=Carnes|first2=Donna|title=The Myth of Closure|journal=Family Process|date=December 2012|volume=51|issue=4|pages=456–469|doi=10.1111/famp.12005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Pauline Boss — The Myth of Closure -|url=https://onbeing.org/programs/pauline-boss-the-myth-of-closure/|newspaper=On Being}}</ref> Grief in ambiguous loss can be both beneficial and difficult. Since the grief in an ambiguous loss differs than the linear stages of [[grief]] there is no pressure to move on or achieve closure, and this allows for people to remember the lost loved one and move on with relationships and life.<ref name=ClosureMyth/> There are three specific types of grief that can develop from the type of ambiguous loss. ====Anticipatory grief==== Anticipatory grief occurs before bereavement, mourning after death occurs, and upon realizing that death may be imminent for a loved one, anticipatory grief sets in.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Coombs|first1=MA|title=The mourning before: can anticipatory grief theory inform family care in adult intensive care?|journal=International journal of palliative nursing|date=December 2010|volume=16|issue=12|page=481|pmid=21240101|doi=10.12968/ijpn.2010.16.12.580}}</ref><ref name=ClosureMyth/> This type of grief is common among families who have a loved one living with Alzheimer's disease. The grief becomes anticipatory due to the knowledge that the loved one's mental state will only become worse, so the grieving process can start very early.<ref name=ClosureMyth/>
====Disenfranchised grief==== The second type of grief that can develop from an ambiguous loss is disenfranchised grief.<ref name=ClosureMyth /><ref name=PetLoss>{{cite journal|last1=Cordaro|first1=Millie|title=Pet Loss and Disenfranchised Grief: Implications for Mental Health Counseling Practice.|journal=Journal of Mental Health Counseling|date=October 2012|volume=34|issue=4|pages=283-294}}</ref> It is also known as unrecognized grief because it often occurs in the loss of a beloved pet and the grief is not taken seriously.<ref name=ClosureMyth /><ref name=PetLoss/> ====Frozen grief==== Frozen grief is the third type of grief, it is a result of the ambiguity of death because of the physical or psychological disappearance and therefore one's grief is frozen since they do not get a chance to let grief run a normal course.<ref name=ClosureMyth /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Boss|first1=Pauline|title=The Trauma and Complicated Grief of Ambiguous Loss|journal=Pastoral Psychology|date=11 November 2009|volume=59|issue=2|pages=137–145|doi=10.1007/s11089-009-0264-0}}</ref>
==Origins== The term "ambiguous loss" was first used in the 1970s by Pauline Boss, a researcher who studied families of soldiers who went missing in action and coined the term in the late 1970s.<ref name=ClosureMyth /> During her research, Boss, had previously used the term boundary ambiguity from 1973 up until 1977, and that term was later replaced with ambiguous loss in 1977.<ref name=ClosureMyth />
== References == {{reflist}}

'''Amphicarpy''' is a [[reproductive strategy]] that occurs with nine plant families,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cheplick|first=Gregory Paul|title=The ecology of amphicarpic plants|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0169-5347(87)90166-2|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=2|issue=4|pages=97–101|doi=10.1016/0169-5347(87)90166-2}}</ref> expressed mostly in species with an annual life cycle.<ref>{{cite book|title= Evolution: Essays in Honour of John Maynard Smith|first1= Paul J.|last1= Greenwood|first2= Paul H.|last2= Harvey|first3= Montgomery|last3= Slatkin|publisher= CUP Archive|year= 1985|isbn= 9780521257343 |page= 149 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=nQw5AAAAIAAJ}}</ref> It is characterized by production of two types of fruit, for different ecological roles.<ref>{{citation |author=Beentje, H. |author2=Williamson, J. |last-author-amp=yes |year=2010 |title=The Kew Plant Glossary: an Illustrated Dictionary of Plant Terms |publisher=Kew Publishing |location=Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew}}</ref><ref>{{citation |author=Hickey, M. |author2=King, C. |last-author-amp=yes |year=2001 |title=The Cambridge Illustrated Glossary of Botanical Terms |publisher=Cambridge University Press}}</ref><ref name=dictionary.com/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Swift|first=Joel F.|last2=Smith|first2=Stacy A.|last3=Menges|first3=Eric S.|last4=Bassüner|first4=Burgund|last5=Edwards|first5=Christine E.|date=2016-12-01|title=Analysis of mating system and genetic structure in the endangered, amphicarpic plant, Lewton’s polygala (Polygala lewtonii)|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10592-016-0860-3|journal=Conservation Genetics|language=en|volume=17|issue=6|pages=1269–1284|doi=10.1007/s10592-016-0860-3|issn=1566-0621}}</ref> It is sometimes restricted to the situation where one fruit type is aerial and the other subterranean (hypogeous),<ref>{{citation |title=The Heterodiaspory of ''Capsella bursa-pastoris'' (Brassicaceae) |author=Herwig Teppner |pages=381–391 |journal=Phyton |volume=43 |issue=2 |year=2003}}</ref> and distinguished from '''heterocarpy'''. The word amphicarp is the contraction of the Greek words ''ἀμφί'' meaning "of both kinds" and ''καρπός'' meaning fruit.<!---The concept of amphicarpy was probably coined by Ernst HUTH 1890 in hiw Ueber Geokarpe, Amphikarpe, und Heterokarpe Pflanzen, but I have not been able to see it---><ref name=dictionary.com>{{cite web|website= Dictionary.com |title= Amphicarpous |url= http://www.dictionary.com/browse/amphicarpous|accessdate= 2016-12-25}}</ref>
In a typical plant with amphicarpy, one fruit type is underground. These [[Geocarpy|underground fruits]] usually develop from [[Self-pollination|self-pollinating]] flowers. The fruits that develop from the aerial flowers may often be the result of [[Pollination#Mechanism|cross-pollination]].<ref>{{cite book|first= Focko|last= Weberling|year= 1992|title= Morphology of Flowers and Inflorescences|publisher= CUP Archive|isbn= 9780521438322|page= 345 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?redir_esc=y&id=-ZlOAAAAIAAJ}}</ref>
Plants use this strategy to increase the chance that their genetic material is passed on. It can be referred to as [[Bet-hedging (biology)|bet hedging]] in which an organism produces several different [[phenotypes]]. Seeds from the underground flowers have low genetic variability (due to their selfing), tend to be larger, and may germinate from within the tissues of the flower, so ensuring that the annual can remain at the site that was suitable to it in the preceding year. Seeds from aerial flowers usually have greater genetic variability, tend to be smaller, and may be spread further. This assists the colonization of new territory, but also helps the exchange of genetic material between populations.<ref name=RdC>{{cite journal|first= E.|last= Ruiz de Clavijo|year= 1995|title= The Ecological Significance of Fruit Heteromorphism in the Amphicarpic Species ''Catananche lutea'' (Asteraceae)|journal= International Journal of Plant Sciences|volume= 156|issue= 6|pages= 824–833|jstor= 2475114|doi=10.1086/297306}}</ref>
Worldwide, approximately fifty species exhibit amphicarpy, or 0.02% of the known species of flowering plants. Most of these fifty species occur in often disturbed or very stressful circumstances. In Israel, a country that harbors many disturbed habitats, with eight out of a total flora of twenty five hundred species, a much higher percentage of 0.32% is amphicarpic.<ref>{{cite book|first1= Vicki A.|last1= Funk|first2= Ori|last2= Fragman-Sapir|year= 2009|chapter= 22. Gymnarrheneae (Gymnarrhenoideae)|title= Systematics, Evolution, and Biogeography of Compositae|publisher= [[International Association for Plant Taxonomy]]|location= Vienna|editor= V.A. Funk|editor2= A. Susanna|editor3= T. Stuessy|editor4= R. Bayer| pages= 327–332|url= https://botany.si.edu/bdg/pdf/funkyarchive/funkypdf/2009_pr_Funk_Fragman-Sapir_Gymnarrheneae.pdf|accessdate= 2016-12-27}}</ref> Species that use amphicarpy include ''[[Catananche lutea]]'', ''[[Gymnarrhena micrantha]]'' and ''[[Polygala lewtonii]]''.<ref name=RdC /><ref>{{cite journal|first1=Dov|last1= Koller|first2= Nurit|last2= Roth|year= 1964|title= Studies on the Ecological and Physiological Significance of Amphicarpy in ''Gymnarrhena micrantha'' (Compositae)|journal= American Journal of Botany|volume= 51|issue= 1|pages= 26–35|jstor= 2440059|doi=10.2307/2440059}}</ref><ref name=arch>{{citation|title= Lewton’s polygala (''Polygala lewtonii''), 5-Year Review: Summary and Evaluation |author= U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service |url= https://ecos.fws.gov/docs/five_year_review/doc3261.pdf |accessdate= 2016-12-25}}</ref> ''[[Trifolium polymorphum]]'' is a perennial, that combines amphicarpy with [[vegetative reproduction]] through [[stolon]]s. It grows in grasslands where its aerial flowers may not come into seed due to herbivores.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= Speroni|first1= G.|last2= Izaguirre|first2= P.|last3= Bernardello|first3= G.|last4= Franco|first4= J.|year= 2014|title= Reproductive versatility in legumes: the case of amphicarpy in ''Trifolium polymorphum'' |journal= Plant Biology |volume=16 |issue= 3|pages= 690–6|location= Stuttg|doi= 10.1111/plb.12113}}</ref>
